title.value: To Infinity and Beyond: Comparing the size of infinite sets

summary.value:
Cardinality is the word that mathematicians use for the "size" of a set.

It is straightforward to compare the size of finite sets: just count the elements. Thus the cardinality of a finite set is just the number of elements it contains.

For infinite sets, the notion of size first needs to be defined in a more rigorous and abstract manner. We do this by using the language of functions and saying that two sets are the same size if there is bijection (or one-one correspondence) between them. A bijection between sets A and B is a function that:

  • Maps every element of A to a different element of B (one-one)
  • makes sure that every element of B has an element of A that is mapped to it (onto)

For example, by creating a bijection between and we can show that they have the same cardinality, even though is a strict subset of .

It turns out with this definition that all infinite subsets of are the same size, even though they may vary greatly in their composition. More surprisingly, , the set of rational numbers, is also the same size, even though intuitively it seems much bigger. Sets such as , or are said to be countably infinite and their cardinality is denoted by (Aleph null) - the lowest infinity

When it comes to the set of all real numbers, however, the story is different. Cantor's diagonalization argument provides a proof that there is no bijection between the natural numbers and all real numbers. In this sense, really is much bigger than , and . The cardinality of is denoted by . We can therefore write meaningfully that > , even though both these numbers are infinite.

The continuum hypothesis asserts that there is nothing in between and . In other words, any subset of must either be finite, the same size as or the same sizes as itself. This is an open question.

brief.value: Infinity is a tricky buy intriguing concept. We make reference to it in many places in A level Maths in relation to sequences, limits and the cardinality (size) of sets. In this brick, we investigate infinite sets.
